title: Ilona Bruzsenyák
text:
Ilona Bruzsenyák (born 14 September 1950) is a <a href="Hungary">Hungarian</a> former <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> athlete who competed in the <a href="women%27s%20pentathlon">women's pentathlon</a>, <a href="long%20jump">long jump</a> and <a href="100%20metres%20hurdles">100 metres hurdles</a>. She was the gold medallist in the long jump at the <a href="1974%20European%20Athletics%20Championships">1974 European Athletics Championships</a>. Bruzsenyák represented her nation at the <a href="Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympics</a> in 1972 and 1976, competing in both long jump and pentathlon. She was a ten-time national champion at the <a href="Hungarian%20Athletics%20Championships">Hungarian Athletics Championships</a>.
Career.
Born in <a href="P%C3%B3csmegyer">Pócsmegyer</a> in Hungary's <a href="Pest%20County">Pest County</a>, she joined the Debreceni Egyetem <a href="athletics%20%28sport%29">athletics</a> club in <a href="Debrecen">Debrecen</a> before moving to <a href="Budapest">Budapest</a> and training with <a href="%C3%9Ajpesti%20TE">Újpesti TE</a>. Her first national title came at the <a href="Hungarian%20Athletics%20Championships">Hungarian Athletics Championships</a> in 1971, where she won the <a href="women%27s%20pentathlon">women's pentathlon</a> in a meet record of 4897 points, succeeding <a href="Margit%20Papp">Margit Papp</a> to the crown. An international debut followed at the <a href="1971%20European%20Athletics%20Championships">1971 European Athletics Championships</a>. Papp was chosen as the representative in the pentathlon so Bruzsenyák competed as part of the <a href="4%20%C3%97%20100%20metres%20relay">4 × 100 metres relay</a> team and she led off the team of <a href="Margit%20Nemesh%C3%A1zi">Margit Nemesházi</a>, <a href="Gy%C3%B6rgyi%20Balogh">Györgyi Balogh</a> and <a href="Katalin%20Papp">Katalin Papp</a> to take fifth place.
She was a double national champion in 1972, winning in both pentathlon and <a href="100%20metres%20hurdles">100 metres hurdles</a>. She was chosen to compete for Hungary at the <a href="1972%20Summer%20Olympics">1972 Summer Olympics</a> and finished tenth in the long jump and eighth in the pentathlon (outperforming Papp in latter). She repeated her national wins in 1973 and made her first outing at a major international indoors, taking fifth in the <a href="60%20metres%20hurdles">60 metres hurdles</a> at the <a href="1973%20European%20Athletics%20Indoor%20Championships">1973 European Athletics Indoor Championships</a>. She also topped the podium at the pentathlon semi-final of the <a href="European%20Combined%20Events%20Cup">European Combined Events Cup</a>.
The peak of her career came in the 1974 season. She started with an indoor national double in the 60 m hurdles and <a href="60%20metres">60 metres</a> sprint. She placed sixth at the <a href="1974%20European%20Athletics%20Indoor%20Championships">1974 European Athletics Indoor Championships</a> in the hurdles. Outdoors she proved herself as Hungary's most versatile athlete with wins in the long jump, 100 m hurdles and pentathlon. Her winning mark of in the long jump was a personal best for the athlete and a Hungarian championship record. She was selected for both long jump at the pentathlon at the <a href="1974%20European%20Athletics%20Championships">1974 European Athletics Championships</a>. Her first final was the long jump and she produced a lifetime best performance of to break the <a href="List%20of%20Hungarian%20records%20in%20athletics">Hungarian national record</a> and take the gold medal ahead of <a href="Eva%20%C5%A0uranov%C3%A1">Eva Šuranová</a> of Czechoslovakia. Despite this additional efforts, she still managed to place sixth in the pentathlon event and was the only athlete in the top seven not to come from either <a href="East%20Germany">East Germany</a> or the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. For her achievements she was chosen as the <a href="Hungarian%20Sportspeople%20of%20the%20Year">Hungarian Sportswoman of the Year</a>.
Bruzsenyák did not compete in major international competition in 1975, but took national indoor titles in the hurdles and long jump that year. The 1976 season was her last at a high level. She was the sprint hurdles champion indoors and outdoors. Alongside the national champions <a href="Ildik%C3%B3%20Erd%C3%A9lyi">Ildikó Erdélyi</a> and Margit Papp, she was chosen again for the long jump and pentathlon at the Olympics. At the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201976%20Summer%20Olympics">1976 Montreal Games</a> her decline on the international scene was evident as she failed to progress beyond the long jump qualifiers and dropped to sixteenth in the pentathlon rankings. The following year she won the last national title of her career, the indoor 60 m hurdles.
Bruzsenyák married <a href="Lajos%20Gresa">Lajos Gresa</a>, a fellow Hungarian international athlete.
